text:
News Blaze hero becomes firefighter after winning Pride of Britain Award for saving OAP Asda worker Will Edwards pulled 73-year-old Anne Wade from her burning vehicle and was so inspired by the fire crew he saw that day that he decided to sign up Share Heroic driver Will Edwards (left) and his new crew mates celebrate Pancake Day (Photo: North Wales Fire and Rescue Service)   
Hero Will Edwards has become a firefighter - after receiving a Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Award for saving a pensioner’s life. 
Will has just completed his first shift on call as a retained firefighter with North Wales Fire and Rescue Service. 
The 26-year-old home shopping section leader at Asda in Wrexham, smashed a car window and dragged 73-year-old Anne Wade to safety from her blazing vehicle on the M60 in Greater Manchester. 
She’d stopped on a slip road after the heater failed, smoke and flames started coming out of the bonnet, and the doors wouldn’t open. 
Will says he was so inspired by the fire crew that arrived to deal with the blaze that he decided to sign up as a part-timer. Will was inspired to sign up as a part-timer (Photo: North Wales Fire and Rescue Service) Proud Will when he won Outstanding Bravery award at Pride of Britain (Photo: ITV) 
“It feels great. I’m so proud of myself and I think a lot of people are as well,” he said. 
“It’s something that I have a lot of pride in, working for them. It’s a goal that I set after the incident and I have achieved it.” Read More Pride of Britain winners 2016: Inspiring stories of heroes that embody the best of the UK 
Will was a passenger in a car travelling on the motorway when he noticed the fire. 
The car was almost fully ablaze, and Will smashed through the glass of the car door, cutting his arm and severing two tendons before dragging the OAP from the wreckage. With the cast of Strictly Come Dancing during the awards (Photo: Adam Sorenson/Daily Mirror) 
The electrics had failed meaning the doors were locked and she was trapped so Will tried to break the driver’s side window with his arm. 
He spent two days in hospital after the fire, which happened in December 2015. Read More 10 Pride of Britain moments to warm the heart, from Stephen Sutton to Malala Yousafzai 
He received a bravery award from Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service for his efforts. 
And he collected a Pride of Britain at at London’ Grosvenor House Hotel in October (2016) where guests included Prime Minister Theresa May, Prince Charles, and Simon Cowell. Will at the spot where he saved Anne (Photo: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror) 
Will said: “After coming back to North Wales from Manchester, and after helping Anne I really wanted to do my bit in the community and I thought that there’s no better way of being able to help people than being in the fire service, and that’s why I joined,” he added. 
He completed a six-day training course at Dolgellau Fire Station earlier this month. 
Will attends drill sessions at Johnstown Fire Station every Tuesday and will complete further training in the near future. 
He said Anne Wade was “over the moon” that he had accomplished his goal. Like us on Facebook
